question: Consider the integral \par \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{-1.0}^{0.4} (1.2 t^{2}) e^{+ x (- 2.9 t^{2} - 1.0 t - 2.6)} \, dt \end{equation} \par Develop an analytical formula for $I(x)$ that is accurate as $x \to \infty$.
solution: The integral is of the form \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{a}^{b} g(t) e^{+ x f(t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par where $ a=-1.0$ , $ b=0.4$ , $ g(t) = 1.2 t^{2}$ , and $ f(t) = - 2.9 t^{2} - 1.0 t - 2.6$ . This means we can use Laplace's method to develop an analytical approximation in the limit that $ x \to \infty$ . \par In this limit, the integral will be dominated by the integrand near the maximum of $ f(t)$  within the bounds $ [-1.0, 0.4]$ . So, to simplify the integral, we will expand the integrand around this maximum. \par In this case, we can find the maximum of $ f(t) = - 2.9 t^{2} - 1.0 t - 2.6$  on the interval analytically. We begin by looking for critical point(s) $ t_{crit}$  of $ f(t)$  by solving $ f'(t) = - 5.8 t - 1.0 = 0$  for $ t$ . This gives us that $ t_{crit} = [-0.172413793103448]$ . To find the maximum on this interval, we evaluate $ f(t)$  at the critical point(s) $ t_{crit}$  and the bounds $ -1.0$  and $ 0.4$ . We take the $ t$  that gives the largest value. Here, this maximum $ t_0 = [-0.172413793103448]$ . \par Since the integral is dominated by the value of the integrand near -0.172413793103448, we Taylor expand the integrand around this point. \begin{equation} I(x) =  \int_{a}^{b} (g(-0.172413793103448) + (t--0.172413793103448)g'(-0.172413793103448)+...) e^{+ x (f(-0.172413793103448) + (t--0.172413793103448) f'(-0.172413793103448) + \frac{(t--0.172413793103448)^2}{2} f''(-0.172413793103448) +...)} \end{equation}But $ f'(-0.172413793103448) = 0$  by definition, so we can remove this term from the exponent. We can then approximate \begin{equation} I(x) \approx \int_{a}^{b} g(-0.172413793103448) e^{+ x (f(-0.172413793103448) + \frac{(t--0.172413793103448)^2}{2} f''(-0.172413793103448))} \, dt \end{equation} \par Which equals \par \begin{equation} = g(-0.172413793103448) e^{+ x f(-0.172413793103448)} \int_{a}^{b} e^{+ x (\frac{(t--0.172413793103448)^2}{2} f''(-0.172413793103448))} \, dt \end{equation} \par Because $ x$  is large, we perform the change of variables $ u = \sqrt{x \frac{|f''(-0.172413793103448)|}{2}}(t--0.172413793103448)$ , rewriting the integral as \begin{equation} g(-0.172413793103448) e^{+ x f(-0.172413793103448)} \int_{\sqrt{x \frac{|f''(-0.172413793103448)|}{2}} (a--0.172413793103448)}^{\sqrt{x \frac{|f''(-0.172413793103448)|}{2}} (b--0.172413793103448)} \sqrt{\frac{2}{x |f''(-0.172413793103448)|}} e^{-u^2} \, dt \end{equation} \par Since $ x \to \infty$ , we approximate this as \begin{equation} g(-0.172413793103448) e^{+ x f(-0.172413793103448)} \sqrt{\frac{2}{x |f''(-0.172413793103448)|} } \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-u^2} \, dt \end{equation} \par Solving the integral and evaluating, we find that \par \begin{equation} \boxed{I(x) \approx 0.0209472135379799 \sqrt{\pi} \sqrt{\frac{1}{x}} e^{- 2.51379310344828 x}} \end{equation}

question: Consider the integral \par \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{-0.7}^{0.5} (- 1.9 t^{2} - 0.7 t - 0.7 \sin{\left(t \right)} - 3.4 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)}) e^{+ x (0.9 t^{3} + 0.1 \sin{\left(t \right)} - 2.0)} \, dt \end{equation} \par Develop an analytical formula for $I(x)$ that is accurate as $x \to \infty$.
solution: The integral is of the form \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{a}^{b} g(t) e^{+ x f(t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par where $ a=-0.7$ , $ b=0.5$ , $ g(t) = - 1.9 t^{2} - 0.7 t - 0.7 \sin{\left(t \right)} - 3.4 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)}$ , and $ f(t) = 0.9 t^{3} + 0.1 \sin{\left(t \right)} - 2.0$ . This means we can use Laplace's method to develop an analytical approximation in the limit that $ x \to \infty$ . \par In this limit, the integral will be dominated by the integrand near the maximum of $ f(t)$  within the bounds $ [-0.7, 0.5]$ . So, to simplify the integral, we will expand the integrand around this maximum. \par However, it is impossible to compute the maximum of $ f(t)$  on the bounds analytically. We must approximate it numerically. We will use the a few iterations of the dual annealing algorithm to achieve this. Using a few iterations of dual annealing, we find that the maximum of $ f(t)$  occurs at $ t_0 = [0.5]$ . \par Since the integral is dominated by the value of the integrand near b, we Taylor expand the integrand around this point. \begin{equation} I(x) =  \int_{a}^{b} (g(b) + (t-b)g'(b)+...) e^{+ x (f(b) + (t-b) f'(b) + ...)} \, dt \end{equation} We can then approximate \begin{equation} I(x) \approx \int_{a}^{b} g(b) e^{+ x (f(b) + (t-b) f'(b))} \, dt \end{equation} Pulling out the constant in the integral gives \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{+ x f(b)} \int_{a}^{b} e^{+ x (t-b) f'(b)}  \, dt \end{equation} \par Since $ x$  is large, we perform the change of variables $ u = x (t-b) |f'(b)|$ , rewriting the integral as \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{+ x f(b)} \int_{x (a-b) |f'(b)|}^{0} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} Since $ x \to \infty$ , we approximate this with new bounds as \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{+ x f(b)} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} \int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} \par Solving the integral and evaluating, we find that \par \begin{equation} \boxed{I(x) \approx - \frac{3.5882925231128 e^{- 1.83955744613958 x}}{x}} \end{equation}

question: Consider the integral \par \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{-0.4}^{-0.0} (- 2.1 \sin{\left(t \right)} - 0.3 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)}) e^{- x (1.6 t + 0.3 \cos{\left(t \right)})} \, dt \end{equation} \par Develop an analytical formula for $I(x)$ that is accurate as $x \to \infty$.
solution: The integral is of the form \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{a}^{b} g(t) e^{- x f(t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par where $ a=-0.4$ , $ b=-0.0$ , $ g(t) = - 2.1 \sin{\left(t \right)} - 0.3 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)}$ , and $ f(t) = 1.6 t + 0.3 \cos{\left(t \right)}$ . This means we can use Laplace's method to develop an analytical approximation in the limit that $ x \to \infty$ . \par In this limit, the integral will be dominated by the integrand near the minimum of $ f(t)$  within the bounds $ [-0.4, -0.0]$ . So, to simplify the integral, we will expand the integrand around this minimum. \par In this case, we can find the minimum of $ f(t) = 1.6 t + 0.3 \cos{\left(t \right)}$  on the interval analytically. We begin by looking for critical point(s) $ t_{crit}$  of $ f(t)$  by solving $ f'(t) = 1.6 - 0.3 \sin{\left(t \right)} = 0$  for $ t$ . We find that there are no critical points of $ f(t) \in (-0.4, -0.0)$ . This means that its minimum must be on the bounds. Comparing the values of $ f(t)$  on the bounds, we find that its minimum occurs at $ t_0 = a = -0.4$ . \par Since the integral is dominated by the value of the integrand near a, we Taylor expand the integrand around this point. \begin{equation} I(x) =  \int_{a}^{b} (g(a) + (t-a)g'(a)+...) e^{- x (f(a) + (t-a) f'(a) + ...)} \, dt \end{equation} We can then approximate \begin{equation} I(x) \approx \int_{a}^{b} g(a) e^{- x (f(a) + (t-a) f'(a))} \, dt \end{equation} Pulling out the constant in the integral gives \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(a) e^{- x f(a)} \int_{a}^{b} e^{- x (t-a) f'(a)}  \, dt \end{equation} \par Since $ x$  is large, we perform the change of variables $ u = x (t-a) |f'(a)|$ , rewriting the integral as \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(a) e^{- x f(a)} \int_{0}^{x (b-a) |f'(a)|} \frac{1}{x |f'(a)|} e^{-u} \, dt \end{equation} Since $ x \to \infty$ , we approximate this with new bounds as \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(a) e^{- x f(a)} \frac{1}{x |f'(a)|} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-u} \, dt \end{equation} \par Solving the integral and evaluating, we find that \par \begin{equation} \boxed{I(x) \approx \frac{0.542821871250326 e^{0.363681701799135 x}}{x}} \end{equation}

question: Consider the integral \par \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{-1.0}^{0.6} (- 2.6 t + 1.0 \cos{\left(t \right)} - 3.0 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)}) e^{+ x (1.7 t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par Develop an analytical formula for $I(x)$ that is accurate as $x \to \infty$.
solution: The integral is of the form \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{a}^{b} g(t) e^{+ x f(t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par where $ a=-1.0$ , $ b=0.6$ , $ g(t) = - 2.6 t + 1.0 \cos{\left(t \right)} - 3.0 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)}$ , and $ f(t) = 1.7 t$ . This means we can use Laplace's method to develop an analytical approximation in the limit that $ x \to \infty$ . \par In this limit, the integral will be dominated by the integrand near the maximum of $ f(t)$  within the bounds $ [-1.0, 0.6]$ . So, to simplify the integral, we will expand the integrand around this maximum. \par In this case, we can find the maximum of $ f(t) = 1.7 t$  on the interval analytically. We begin by looking for critical point(s) $ t_{crit}$  of $ f(t)$  by solving $ f'(t) = 1.7 = 0$  for $ t$ . We find that there are no critical points of $ f(t) \in (-1.0, 0.6)$ . This means that its maximum must be on the bounds. Comparing the values of $ f(t)$  on the bounds, we find that its maximum occurs at $ t_0 = b = 0.6$ . \par Since the integral is dominated by the value of the integrand near b, we Taylor expand the integrand around this point. \begin{equation} I(x) =  \int_{a}^{b} (g(b) + (t-b)g'(b)+...) e^{+ x (f(b) + (t-b) f'(b) + ...)} \, dt \end{equation} We can then approximate \begin{equation} I(x) \approx \int_{a}^{b} g(b) e^{+ x (f(b) + (t-b) f'(b))} \, dt \end{equation} Pulling out the constant in the integral gives \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{+ x f(b)} \int_{a}^{b} e^{+ x (t-b) f'(b)}  \, dt \end{equation} \par Since $ x$  is large, we perform the change of variables $ u = x (t-b) |f'(b)|$ , rewriting the integral as \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{+ x f(b)} \int_{x (a-b) |f'(b)|}^{0} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} Since $ x \to \infty$ , we approximate this with new bounds as \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{+ x f(b)} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} \int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} \par Solving the integral and evaluating, we find that \par \begin{equation} \boxed{I(x) \approx - \frac{1.3858369917071 e^{1.02 x}}{x}} \end{equation}

question: Consider the integral \par \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{-0.6}^{0.5} (0.8 t^{5} - 0.6 t^{4} - 0.9 t + 1.0 \sin{\left(t \right)} - 2.9 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)}) e^{- x (- 0.9 t - 0.3 \sin{\left(t \right)})} \, dt \end{equation} \par Develop an analytical formula for $I(x)$ that is accurate as $x \to \infty$.
solution: The integral is of the form \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{a}^{b} g(t) e^{- x f(t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par where $ a=-0.6$ , $ b=0.5$ , $ g(t) = 0.8 t^{5} - 0.6 t^{4} - 0.9 t + 1.0 \sin{\left(t \right)} - 2.9 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)}$ , and $ f(t) = - 0.9 t - 0.3 \sin{\left(t \right)}$ . This means we can use Laplace's method to develop an analytical approximation in the limit that $ x \to \infty$ . \par In this limit, the integral will be dominated by the integrand near the minimum of $ f(t)$  within the bounds $ [-0.6, 0.5]$ . So, to simplify the integral, we will expand the integrand around this minimum. \par In this case, we can find the minimum of $ f(t) = - 0.9 t - 0.3 \sin{\left(t \right)}$  on the interval analytically. We begin by looking for critical point(s) $ t_{crit}$  of $ f(t)$  by solving $ f'(t) = - 0.3 \cos{\left(t \right)} - 0.9 = 0$  for $ t$ . We find that there are no critical points of $ f(t) \in (-0.6, 0.5)$ . This means that its minimum must be on the bounds. Comparing the values of $ f(t)$  on the bounds, we find that its minimum occurs at $ t_0 = b = 0.5$ . \par Since the integral is dominated by the value of the integrand near b, we Taylor expand the integrand around this point. \begin{equation} I(x) =  \int_{a}^{b} (g(b) + (t-b)g'(b)+...) e^{- x (f(b) + (t-b) f'(b) + ...)} \, dt \end{equation} We can then approximate \begin{equation} I(x) \approx \int_{a}^{b} g(b) e^{- x (f(b) + (t-b) f'(b))} \, dt \end{equation} Pulling out the constant in the integral gives \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \int_{a}^{b} e^{- x (t-b) f'(b)}  \, dt \end{equation} \par Since $ x$  is large, we perform the change of variables $ u = x (t-b) |f'(b)|$ . Note $ f'(b) < 0$  since it is a minimum. So, rewriting the integral, we get \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \int_{x (a-b) |f'(b)|}^{0} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} Since $ x \to \infty$ , we approximate this with new bounds as \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} \int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} \par Solving the integral and evaluating, we find that \par \begin{equation} \boxed{I(x) \approx - \frac{1.14130604683664 e^{0.593827661581261 x}}{x}} \end{equation}

question: Consider the integral \par \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{-0.7}^{-0.6} (- 1.2 t^{4} - 3.0 t^{3} + 1.6 \sin{\left(t \right)} + 1.1 \cos{\left(t \right)}) e^{- x (- 4.0 t^{5})} \, dt \end{equation} \par Develop an analytical formula for $I(x)$ that is accurate as $x \to \infty$.
solution: The integral is of the form \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{a}^{b} g(t) e^{- x f(t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par where $ a=-0.7$ , $ b=-0.6$ , $ g(t) = - 1.2 t^{4} - 3.0 t^{3} + 1.6 \sin{\left(t \right)} + 1.1 \cos{\left(t \right)}$ , and $ f(t) = - 4.0 t^{5}$ . This means we can use Laplace's method to develop an analytical approximation in the limit that $ x \to \infty$ . \par In this limit, the integral will be dominated by the integrand near the minimum of $ f(t)$  within the bounds $ [-0.7, -0.6]$ . So, to simplify the integral, we will expand the integrand around this minimum. \par In this case, we can find the minimum of $ f(t) = - 4.0 t^{5}$  on the interval analytically. We begin by looking for critical point(s) $ t_{crit}$  of $ f(t)$  by solving $ f'(t) = - 20.0 t^{4} = 0$  for $ t$ . We find that there are no critical points of $ f(t) \in (-0.7, -0.6)$ . This means that its minimum must be on the bounds. Comparing the values of $ f(t)$  on the bounds, we find that its minimum occurs at $ t_0 = b = -0.6$ . \par Since the integral is dominated by the value of the integrand near b, we Taylor expand the integrand around this point. \begin{equation} I(x) =  \int_{a}^{b} (g(b) + (t-b)g'(b)+...) e^{- x (f(b) + (t-b) f'(b) + ...)} \, dt \end{equation} We can then approximate \begin{equation} I(x) \approx \int_{a}^{b} g(b) e^{- x (f(b) + (t-b) f'(b))} \, dt \end{equation} Pulling out the constant in the integral gives \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \int_{a}^{b} e^{- x (t-b) f'(b)}  \, dt \end{equation} \par Since $ x$  is large, we perform the change of variables $ u = x (t-b) |f'(b)|$ . Note $ f'(b) < 0$  since it is a minimum. So, rewriting the integral, we get \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \int_{x (a-b) |f'(b)|}^{0} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} Since $ x \to \infty$ , we approximate this with new bounds as \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} \int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} \par Solving the integral and evaluating, we find that \par \begin{equation} \boxed{I(x) \approx \frac{0.191713433244055 e^{- 0.31104 x}}{x}} \end{equation}

question: Consider the integral \par \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{-0.7}^{0.4} (2.9 t^{3}) e^{- x (- 2.4 t^{5} + 0.8 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)})} \, dt \end{equation} \par Develop an analytical formula for $I(x)$ that is accurate as $x \to \infty$.
solution: The integral is of the form \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{a}^{b} g(t) e^{- x f(t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par where $ a=-0.7$ , $ b=0.4$ , $ g(t) = 2.9 t^{3}$ , and $ f(t) = - 2.4 t^{5} + 0.8 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)}$ . This means we can use Laplace's method to develop an analytical approximation in the limit that $ x \to \infty$ . \par In this limit, the integral will be dominated by the integrand near the minimum of $ f(t)$  within the bounds $ [-0.7, 0.4]$ . So, to simplify the integral, we will expand the integrand around this minimum. \par In this case, we can find the minimum of $ f(t) = - 2.4 t^{5} + 0.8 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)}$  on the interval analytically. We begin by looking for critical point(s) $ t_{crit}$  of $ f(t)$  by solving $ f'(t) = - 12.0 t^{4} + \frac{0.8}{t^{2} + 1} = 0$  for $ t$ . This gives us that $ t_{crit} = [-0.482252522113940]$ . To find the minimum on this interval, we evaluate $ f(t)$  at the critical point(s) $ t_{crit}$  and the bounds $ -0.7$  and $ 0.4$ . We take the $ t$  that gives the smallest value. Here, this minimum $ t_0 = [-0.482252522113940]$ . \par Since the integral is dominated by the value of the integrand near -0.482252522113940, we Taylor expand the integrand around this point. \begin{equation} I(x) =  \int_{a}^{b} (g(-0.482252522113940) + (t--0.482252522113940)g'(-0.482252522113940)+...) e^{- x (f(-0.482252522113940) + (t--0.482252522113940) f'(-0.482252522113940) + \frac{(t--0.482252522113940)^2}{2} f''(-0.482252522113940) +...)} \end{equation}But $ f'(-0.482252522113940) = 0$  by definition, so we can remove this term from the exponent. We can then approximate \begin{equation} I(x) \approx \int_{a}^{b} g(-0.482252522113940) e^{- x (f(-0.482252522113940) + \frac{(t--0.482252522113940)^2}{2} f''(-0.482252522113940))} \, dt \end{equation} \par Which equals \par \begin{equation} = g(-0.482252522113940) e^{- x f(-0.482252522113940)} \int_{a}^{b} e^{- x (\frac{(t--0.482252522113940)^2}{2} f''(-0.482252522113940))} \, dt \end{equation} \par Because $ x$  is large, we perform the change of variables $ u = \sqrt{x \frac{|f''(-0.482252522113940)|}{2}}(t--0.482252522113940)$ , rewriting the integral as \begin{equation} g(-0.482252522113940) e^{- x f(-0.482252522113940)} \int_{\sqrt{x \frac{|f''(-0.482252522113940)|}{2}} (a--0.482252522113940)}^{\sqrt{x \frac{|f''(-0.482252522113940)|}{2}} (b--0.482252522113940)} \sqrt{\frac{2}{x |f''(-0.482252522113940)|}} e^{-u^2} \, dt \end{equation} \par Since $ x \to \infty$ , we approximate this as \begin{equation} g(-0.482252522113940) e^{- x f(-0.482252522113940)} \sqrt{\frac{2}{x |f''(-0.482252522113940)|} } \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-u^2} \, dt \end{equation} \par Solving the integral and evaluating, we find that \par \begin{equation} \boxed{I(x) \approx - 0.189507963900964 \sqrt{\pi} \sqrt{\frac{1}{x}} e^{0.296877909710412 x}} \end{equation}

Comparing the values of $ f(t)$  on the bounds, we find that its minimum occurs at $ t_0 = b = 0.6$ . \par Since the integral is dominated by the value of the integrand near b, we Taylor expand the integrand around this point. \begin{equation} I(x) =  \int_{a}^{b} (g(b) + (t-b)g'(b)+...) e^{- x (f(b) + (t-b) f'(b) + ...)} \, dt \end{equation} We can then approximate \begin{equation} I(x) \approx \int_{a}^{b} g(b) e^{- x (f(b) + (t-b) f'(b))} \, dt \end{equation} Pulling out the constant in the integral gives \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \int_{a}^{b} e^{- x (t-b) f'(b)}  \, dt \end{equation} \par Since $ x$  is large, we perform the change of variables $ u = x (t-b) |f'(b)|$ . So, rewriting the integral, we get \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \int_{x (a-b) |f'(b)|}^{0} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} Since $ x \to \infty$ , we approximate this with new bounds as \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} \int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} \par Solving the integral and evaluating, we find that \par \begin{equation} \boxed{I(x) \approx \frac{5.75458140928594 e^{0.049248 x}}{x}} \end{equation}

question: Consider the integral \par \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{0.2}^{0.8} (1.9 t^{2}) e^{- x (- 1.2 t^{4} - 2.9 t^{2} - 2.9 t - 0.9 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)} - 2.2)} \, dt \end{equation} \par Develop an analytical formula for $I(x)$ that is accurate as $x \to \infty$.
solution: The integral is of the form \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{a}^{b} g(t) e^{- x f(t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par where $ a=0.2$ , $ b=0.8$ , $ g(t) = 1.9 t^{2}$ , and $ f(t) = - 1.2 t^{4} - 2.9 t^{2} - 2.9 t - 0.9 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)} - 2.2$ . We begin by looking for critical point(s) $ t_{crit}$  of $ f(t)$  by solving $ f'(t) = - 4.8 t^{3} - 5.8 t - 2.9 - \frac{0.9}{t^{2} + 1} = 0$  for $ t$ . Note $ f'(b) < 0$  since it is a minimum. So, rewriting the integral, we get \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \int_{x (a-b) |f'(b)|}^{0} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} Since $ x \to \infty$ , we approximate this with new bounds as \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} \int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} \par Solving the integral and evaluating, we find that \par \begin{equation} \boxed{I(x) \approx \frac{0.115300220905751 e^{7.4747868480012 x}}{x}} \end{equation}

question: Consider the integral \par \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{-0.5}^{0.6} (- 2.8 t^{5} + 2.2 \cos{\left(t \right)}) e^{+ x (- 1.1 t - 2.5 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)})} \, dt \end{equation} \par Develop an analytical formula for $I(x)$ that is accurate as $x \to \infty$.
solution: The integral is of the form \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{a}^{b} g(t) e^{+ x f(t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par where $ a=-0.5$ , $ b=0.6$ , $ g(t) = - 2.8 t^{5} + 2.2 \cos{\left(t \right)}$ , and $ f(t) = - 1.1 t - 2.5 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)}$ . This means we can use Laplace's method to develop an analytical approximation in the limit that $ x \to \infty$ . \par In this limit, the integral will be dominated by the integrand near the maximum of $ f(t)$  within the bounds $ [-0.5, 0.6]$ . We begin by looking for critical point(s) $ t_{crit}$  of $ f(t)$  by solving $ f'(t) = -1.1 - \frac{2.5}{t^{2} + 1} = 0$  for $ t$ . We find that there are no critical points of $ f(t) \in (-0.5, 0.6)$ . This means that its maximum must be on the bounds. Comparing the values of $ f(t)$  on the bounds, we find that its maximum occurs at $ t_0 = a = -0.5$ . \par Since the integral is dominated by the value of the integrand near a, we Taylor expand the integrand around this point. \begin{equation} I(x) =  \int_{a}^{b} (g(a) + (t-a)g'(a)+...) e^{+ x (f(a) + (t-a) f'(a) + ...)} \, dt \end{equation} We can then approximate \begin{equation} I(x) \approx \int_{a}^{b} g(a) e^{+ x (f(a) + (t-a) f'(a))} \, dt \end{equation} Pulling out the constant in the integral gives \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(a) e^{+ x f(a)} \int_{a}^{b} e^{+ x (t-a) f'(a)}  \, dt \end{equation} \par Since $ x$  is large, we perform the change of variables $ u = x (t-a) |f'(a)|$ . Note $ f'(a) < 0$  since it is a maximum. So, rewriting the integral, we get \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(a) e^{+ x f(a)} \int_{0}^{x (b-a) |f'(a)|} \frac{1}{x |f'(a)|} e^{-u} \, dt \end{equation} Since $ x \to \infty$ , we approximate this with new bounds as \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(a) e^{+ x f(a)} \frac{1}{x |f'(a)|} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-u} \, dt \end{equation} \par Solving the integral and evaluating, we find that \par \begin{equation} \boxed{I(x) \approx \frac{0.651026334244781 e^{1.70911902250202 x}}{x}} \end{equation}

question: Consider the integral \par \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{0.2}^{0.5} (0.1 t^{5} + 0.5 t^{3} + 1.2 t^{2} - 0.1 \sin{\left(t \right)}) e^{- x (- 2.6 t^{4} - 2.5 \sin{\left(t \right)} - 0.6 \cos{\left(t \right)})} \, dt \end{equation} \par Develop an analytical formula for $I(x)$ that is accurate as $x \to \infty$.
solution: The integral is of the form \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{a}^{b} g(t) e^{- x f(t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par where $ a=0.2$ , $ b=0.5$ , $ g(t) = 0.1 t^{5} + 0.5 t^{3} + 1.2 t^{2} - 0.1 \sin{\left(t \right)}$ , and $ f(t) = - 2.6 t^{4} - 2.5 \sin{\left(t \right)} - 0.6 \cos{\left(t \right)}$ . This means we can use Laplace's method to develop an analytical approximation in the limit that $ x \to \infty$ . \par In this limit, the integral will be dominated by the integrand near the minimum of $ f(t)$  within the bounds $ [0.2, 0.5]$ . So, to simplify the integral, we will expand the integrand around this minimum. \par However, it is impossible to compute the minimum of $ f(t)$  on the bounds analytically. We must approximate it numerically. We will use the a few iterations of the dual annealing algorithm to achieve this. Using a few iterations of dual annealing, we find that the minimum of $ f(t)$  occurs at $ t_0 = [0.5]$ . \par Since the integral is dominated by the value of the integrand near b, we Taylor expand the integrand around this point. \begin{equation} I(x) =  \int_{a}^{b} (g(b) + (t-b)g'(b)+...) e^{- x (f(b) + (t-b) f'(b) + ...)} \, dt \end{equation} We can then approximate \begin{equation} I(x) \approx \int_{a}^{b} g(b) e^{- x (f(b) + (t-b) f'(b))} \, dt \end{equation} Pulling out the constant in the integral gives \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \int_{a}^{b} e^{- x (t-b) f'(b)}  \, dt \end{equation} \par Since $ x$  is large, we perform the change of variables $ u = x (t-b) |f'(b)|$ . Note $ f'(b) < 0$  since it is a minimum. So, rewriting the integral, we get \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \int_{x (a-b) |f'(b)|}^{0} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} Since $ x \to \infty$ , we approximate this with new bounds as \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} \int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} \par Solving the integral and evaluating, we find that \par \begin{equation} \boxed{I(x) \approx \frac{0.0990806658695558 e^{1.88761338364473 x}}{x}} \end{equation}

question: Consider the integral \par \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{-0.9}^{0.2} (- 2.3 t - 1.5 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)} - 1.4) e^{- x (2.7 t^{2} + 0.5 \cos{\left(t \right)} + 0.7)} \, dt \end{equation} \par Develop an analytical formula for $I(x)$ that is accurate as $x \to \infty$.
solution: The integral is of the form \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{a}^{b} g(t) e^{- x f(t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par where $ a=-0.9$ , $ b=0.2$ , $ g(t) = - 2.3 t - 1.5 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)} - 1.4$ , and $ f(t) = 2.7 t^{2} + 0.5 \cos{\left(t \right)} + 0.7$ . This means we can use Laplace's method to develop an analytical approximation in the limit that $ x \to \infty$ . \par In this limit, the integral will be dominated by the integrand near the minimum of $ f(t)$  within the bounds $ [-0.9, 0.2]$ . So, to simplify the integral, we will expand the integrand around this minimum. \par However, it is impossible to compute the minimum of $ f(t)$  on the bounds analytically. We must approximate it numerically. We will use the a few iterations of the dual annealing algorithm to achieve this. Using a few iterations of dual annealing, we find that the minimum of $ f(t)$  occurs at $ t_0 = [-0.0]$ . \par Since the integral is dominated by the value of the integrand near -0.0, we Taylor expand the integrand around this point. \begin{equation} I(x) =  \int_{a}^{b} (g(-0.0) + (t--0.0)g'(-0.0)+...) e^{- x (f(-0.0) + (t--0.0) f'(-0.0) + \frac{(t--0.0)^2}{2} f''(-0.0) +...)} \end{equation}But $ f'(-0.0) = 0$  by definition, so we can remove this term from the exponent. We can then approximate \begin{equation} I(x) \approx \int_{a}^{b} g(-0.0) e^{- x (f(-0.0) + \frac{(t--0.0)^2}{2} f''(-0.0))} \, dt \end{equation} \par Which equals \par \begin{equation} = g(-0.0) e^{- x f(-0.0)} \int_{a}^{b} e^{- x (\frac{(t--0.0)^2}{2} f''(-0.0))} \, dt \end{equation} \par Because $ x$  is large, we perform the change of variables $ u = \sqrt{x \frac{|f''(-0.0)|}{2}}(t--0.0)$ , rewriting the integral as \begin{equation} g(-0.0) e^{- x f(-0.0)} \int_{\sqrt{x \frac{|f''(-0.0)|}{2}} (a--0.0)}^{\sqrt{x \frac{|f''(-0.0)|}{2}} (b--0.0)} \sqrt{\frac{2}{x |f''(-0.0)|}} e^{-u^2} \, dt \end{equation} \par Since $ x \to \infty$ , we approximate this as \begin{equation} g(-0.0) e^{- x f(-0.0)} \sqrt{\frac{2}{x |f''(-0.0)|} } \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-u^2} \, dt \end{equation} \par Solving the integral and evaluating, we find that \par \begin{equation} \boxed{I(x) \approx - \frac{2 \sqrt{5} \sqrt{\pi} \sqrt{\frac{1}{x}} e^{- \frac{6 x}{5}}}{5}} \end{equation}

question: Consider the integral \par \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{-0.7}^{-0.2} (- 3.0 t^{3} + 1.5 t) e^{+ x (- 1.2 t^{4} + 1.5 t^{3} + 0.7 t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par Develop an analytical formula for $I(x)$ that is accurate as $x \to \infty$.
solution: The integral is of the form \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{a}^{b} g(t) e^{+ x f(t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par where $ a=-0.7$ , $ b=-0.2$ , $ g(t) = - 3.0 t^{3} + 1.5 t$ , and $ f(t) = - 1.2 t^{4} + 1.5 t^{3} + 0.7 t$ . This means we can use Laplace's method to develop an analytical approximation in the limit that $ x \to \infty$ . \par In this limit, the integral will be dominated by the integrand near the maximum of $ f(t)$  within the bounds $ [-0.7, -0.2]$ . So, to simplify the integral, we will expand the integrand around this maximum. \par In this case, we can find the maximum of $ f(t) = - 1.2 t^{4} + 1.5 t^{3} + 0.7 t$  on the interval analytically. We begin by looking for critical point(s) $ t_{crit}$  of $ f(t)$  by solving $ f'(t) = - 4.8 t^{3} + 4.5 t^{2} + 0.7 = 0$  for $ t$ . We find that there are no critical points of $ f(t) \in (-0.7, -0.2)$ . This means that its maximum must be on the bounds. Comparing the values of $ f(t)$  on the bounds, we find that its maximum occurs at $ t_0 = b = -0.2$ . \par Since the integral is dominated by the value of the integrand near b, we Taylor expand the integrand around this point. \begin{equation} I(x) =  \int_{a}^{b} (g(b) + (t-b)g'(b)+...) e^{+ x (f(b) + (t-b) f'(b) + ...)} \, dt \end{equation} We can then approximate \begin{equation} I(x) \approx \int_{a}^{b} g(b) e^{+ x (f(b) + (t-b) f'(b))} \, dt \end{equation} Pulling out the constant in the integral gives \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{+ x f(b)} \int_{a}^{b} e^{+ x (t-b) f'(b)}  \, dt \end{equation} \par Since $ x$  is large, we perform the change of variables $ u = x (t-b) |f'(b)|$ , rewriting the integral as \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{+ x f(b)} \int_{x (a-b) |f'(b)|}^{0} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} Since $ x \to \infty$ , we approximate this with new bounds as \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{+ x f(b)} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} \int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} \par Solving the integral and evaluating, we find that \par \begin{equation} \boxed{I(x) \approx - \frac{0.300522648083624 e^{- 0.15392 x}}{x}} \end{equation}

question: Consider the integral \par \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{-0.1}^{0.1} (- 2.0 t^{5} + 1.6 t^{3}) e^{- x (- 1.1 t^{5} - 1.0 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)})} \, dt \end{equation} \par Develop an analytical formula for $I(x)$ that is accurate as $x \to \infty$.
solution: The integral is of the form \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{a}^{b} g(t) e^{- x f(t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par where $ a=-0.1$ , $ b=0.1$ , $ g(t) = - 2.0 t^{5} + 1.6 t^{3}$ , and $ f(t) = - 1.1 t^{5} - 1.0 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)}$ . This means we can use Laplace's method to develop an analytical approximation in the limit that $ x \to \infty$ . \par In this limit, the integral will be dominated by the integrand near the minimum of $ f(t)$  within the bounds $ [-0.1, 0.1]$ . So, to simplify the integral, we will expand the integrand around this minimum. \par In this case, we can find the minimum of $ f(t) = - 1.1 t^{5} - 1.0 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)}$  on the interval analytically. We begin by looking for critical point(s) $ t_{crit}$  of $ f(t)$  by solving $ f'(t) = - 5.5 t^{4} - \frac{1.0}{t^{2} + 1} = 0$  for $ t$ . We find that there are no critical points of $ f(t) \in (-0.1, 0.1)$ . This means that its minimum must be on the bounds. Comparing the values of $ f(t)$  on the bounds, we find that its minimum occurs at $ t_0 = b = 0.1$ . \par Since the integral is dominated by the value of the integrand near b, we Taylor expand the integrand around this point. \begin{equation} I(x) =  \int_{a}^{b} (g(b) + (t-b)g'(b)+...) e^{- x (f(b) + (t-b) f'(b) + ...)} \, dt \end{equation} We can then approximate \begin{equation} I(x) \approx \int_{a}^{b} g(b) e^{- x (f(b) + (t-b) f'(b))} \, dt \end{equation} Pulling out the constant in the integral gives \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \int_{a}^{b} e^{- x (t-b) f'(b)}  \, dt \end{equation} \par Since $ x$  is large, we perform the change of variables $ u = x (t-b) |f'(b)|$ . Note $ f'(b) < 0$  since it is a minimum. So, rewriting the integral, we get \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \int_{x (a-b) |f'(b)|}^{0} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} Since $ x \to \infty$ , we approximate this with new bounds as \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(b) e^{- x f(b)} \frac{1}{x |f'(b)|} \int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{u} \, dt \end{equation} \par Solving the integral and evaluating, we find that \par \begin{equation} \boxed{I(x) \approx \frac{0.00159491402525897 e^{0.099679652491162 x}}{x}} \end{equation}

question: Consider the integral \par \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{-1.0}^{0.2} (- 1.3 t^{5} + 2.5 t^{2} - 2.9 t - 1.4 \sin{\left(t \right)} - 1.6 \cos{\left(t \right)}) e^{+ x (- 0.8 t^{2} - 1.5 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)} + 2.7)} \, dt \end{equation} \par Develop an analytical formula for $I(x)$ that is accurate as $x \to \infty$.
solution: The integral is of the form \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{a}^{b} g(t) e^{+ x f(t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par where $ a=-1.0$ , $ b=0.2$ , $ g(t) = - 1.3 t^{5} + 2.5 t^{2} - 2.9 t - 1.4 \sin{\left(t \right)} - 1.6 \cos{\left(t \right)}$ , and $ f(t) = - 0.8 t^{2} - 1.5 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)} + 2.7$ . We can then approximate \begin{equation} I(x) \approx \int_{a}^{b} g(-0.655650522251166) e^{+ x (f(-0.655650522251166) + \frac{(t--0.655650522251166)^2}{2} f''(-0.655650522251166))} \, dt \end{equation} \par Which equals \par \begin{equation} = g(-0.655650522251166) e^{+ x f(-0.655650522251166)} \int_{a}^{b} e^{+ x (\frac{(t--0.655650522251166)^2}{2} f''(-0.655650522251166))} \, dt \end{equation} \par Because $ x$  is large, we perform the change of variables $ u = \sqrt{x \frac{|f''(-0.655650522251166)|}{2}}(t--0.655650522251166)$ , rewriting the integral as \begin{equation} g(-0.655650522251166) e^{+ x f(-0.655650522251166)} \int_{\sqrt{x \frac{|f''(-0.655650522251166)|}{2}} (a--0.655650522251166)}^{\sqrt{x \frac{|f''(-0.655650522251166)|}{2}} (b--0.655650522251166)} \sqrt{\frac{2}{x |f''(-0.655650522251166)|}} e^{-u^2} \, dt \end{equation} \par Since $ x \to \infty$ , we approximate this as \begin{equation} g(-0.655650522251166) e^{+ x f(-0.655650522251166)} \sqrt{\frac{2}{x |f''(-0.655650522251166)|} } \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-u^2} \, dt \end{equation} \par Solving the integral and evaluating, we find that \par \begin{equation} \boxed{I(x) \approx 2.40222400850305 \sqrt{\pi} \sqrt{\frac{1}{x}} e^{3.22660374070667 x}} \end{equation}

question: Consider the integral \par \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{-0.0}^{0.5} (- 0.2 \cos{\left(t \right)}) e^{+ x (- 2.6 t^{4} + 0.2 t - 2.3 \cos{\left(t \right)} - 2.1 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)})} \, dt \end{equation} \par Develop an analytical formula for $I(x)$ that is accurate as $x \to \infty$.
solution: The integral is of the form \begin{equation} I(x) = \int_{a}^{b} g(t) e^{+ x f(t)} \, dt \end{equation} \par where $ a=-0.0$ , $ b=0.5$ , $ g(t) = - 0.2 \cos{\left(t \right)}$ , and $ f(t) = - 2.6 t^{4} + 0.2 t - 2.3 \cos{\left(t \right)} - 2.1 \operatorname{atan}{\left(t \right)}$ . This means we can use Laplace's method to develop an analytical approximation in the limit that $ x \to \infty$ . \par In this limit, the integral will be dominated by the integrand near the maximum of $ f(t)$  within the bounds $ [-0.0, 0.5]$ . So, to simplify the integral, we will expand the integrand around this maximum. \par However, it is impossible to compute the maximum of $ f(t)$  on the bounds analytically. We must approximate it numerically. We will use the a few iterations of the dual annealing algorithm to achieve this. Using a few iterations of dual annealing, we find that the maximum of $ f(t)$  occurs at $ t_0 = [0.0]$ . \par Since the integral is dominated by the value of the integrand near a, we Taylor expand the integrand around this point. \begin{equation} I(x) =  \int_{a}^{b} (g(a) + (t-a)g'(a)+...) e^{+ x (f(a) + (t-a) f'(a) + ...)} \, dt \end{equation} We can then approximate \begin{equation} I(x) \approx \int_{a}^{b} g(a) e^{+ x (f(a) + (t-a) f'(a))} \, dt \end{equation} Pulling out the constant in the integral gives \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(a) e^{+ x f(a)} \int_{a}^{b} e^{+ x (t-a) f'(a)}  \, dt \end{equation} \par Since $ x$  is large, we perform the change of variables $ u = x (t-a) |f'(a)|$ . So, rewriting the integral, we get \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(a) e^{+ x f(a)} \int_{0}^{x (b-a) |f'(a)|} \frac{1}{x |f'(a)|} e^{-u} \, dt \end{equation} Since $ x \to \infty$ , we approximate this with new bounds as \begin{equation} I(x) \approx g(a) e^{+ x f(a)} \frac{1}{x |f'(a)|} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-u} \, dt \end{equation} \par Solving the integral and evaluating, we find that \par \begin{equation} \boxed{I(x) \approx - \frac{2 e^{- \frac{23 x}{10}}}{19 x}} \end{equation}
